Message.Title: Just A Thought
Message.Msg: It will be another busy week on the earnings front next week. The one which will probably get the most attention is AAPL which is due to report on Tuesday. It could set a tone for the tech sector and the overall market. Notable earnings due out on Monday include: CAT, HAS, HMA, HAL, NFLX, TXN and CHKP. Besides watching the earnings, keep an eye on the Russell 2000 index. The small cap index was able to hold its support level of 900 in the past three sessions. This opens up the opportunity for it to bounce to the 930 resistance level, suggesting that stocks could get rebound some more next week. However, the intermediate term trend is down. Odds favor more downside after a near term rebound.

Message.Title: I officially am a millionaire because of GOOG call options today!!
Message.Msg: What a day. Bought 900 April 20 795 calls for .15 Sold at various prices throughout the afternoon and sold 600 at a peak of 7. The rest between 1 and 5.75. All put together I raked in well in excess of $500,000. All this with a trade cost of less than $15,000 risk. Am I a genius of what? OK kidding aside I really did buy 50 of the suckers and sold at 5. Nice day indeed but I am kicking myself because I had a feeling the stock was going to have a monster day. I wish I had thrown a lot more at those calls. Days like this don't happen very often. I covered my short on YHOO as well. Too boring....lol

Message.Title: Alibaba Group Dominates China's $190 Billion E-Commerce Market
Message.Msg: China’s e-commerce market racked up a whopping 1.3 trillion RMB ($190 billion USD) worth of transactions in 2012, according to a report by the China Internet Network Information Center (CNNIC) (linked article is in Chinese), an increase of 66.5 percent over 2011′s total. While the latest figures from CNNIC are impressive, China’s e-commerce market still has plenty of room to grow and is set to overtake America’s. As this Economist story notes, the Chinese e-commerce market is currently dominated by Alibaba Group, which last year handled 1.1 trillion yuan ($170 billion USD) in sales through two of its portals, Taobao and Tmall, and is on its way to becoming the first online retail company in the world to handle $1 trillion a year in transactions. Taobao is a C2C marketplace with more than 800 million product listings and 500 million registered users, according to Alibaba. B2C platform Tmall counts major international brands like Microsoft, Nike and Unilever among its 50,000 merchants. Yahoo owns 24% of Alibaba Group.
